actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1227, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes debate on the Houlahan amendment No. 6.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Houlahan,  numbered 6 printed in Part B of House Report 118-511 to strike Section (2) lines 17-19 and strike the word "Biden" throughout the text.
On agreeing to the Nunn (IA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1227, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes debate on the Nunn (IA) amendment No. 5.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Nunn (IA),  numbered 5 printed in Part B of House Report 118-511 to require the Attorney General's report to include data on how many law enforcement officers have been reassigned, and local resources reallocated, to investigate, intercept, and process as evidence fentanyl trafficked from the United States border.
On agreeing to the Nunn (IA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1227, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes debate on the Nunn (IA) amendment No. 4.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Nunn (IA),  numbered 4 printed in Part B of House Report 118-511 to require the Attorney General's report to include costs States had to expend on local law enforcement efforts to investigate, intercept, and process, which includes the collection, analysis, storage, and eventual destruction, fentanyl trafficked from the United States border.
On agreeing to the D'Esposito amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1227, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes debate on the D'Esposito amendment No. 3.

An amendment, offered by Mr. D'Esposito,  numbered 3 printed in Part B of House Report 118-511 to add a provision to the required report to also include the impact that the border crisis has had on law enforcement recruitment.
The Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate on H.R. 8146.
The Speaker designated the Honorable John H. Rutherford to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 1227 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 8369, H.R. 7530, H.R. 7343, H.R. 8146, H.R. 7581, H.R. 354, H. Res. 1213 and H. Res. 1210. Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 8369, H.R. 7530, H.R. 7581, H.R. 354, H. Res. 1213, and H. Res. 1210 under a closed rule with one hour of general debate each. Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 7343 and H.R. 8146 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate each. Rule provides for one motion to recommit each on H.R. 8369, H.R. 7530, H.R. 7343, H.R. 7581, H.R. 354, and H.R. 8146.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 1227. H.R. 8146 — "To require a report by the Attorney General on the impact the border crisis is having on law enforcement at the Federal, State, local, and Tribal level."

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 354, the Chair put the question on passage of the bill and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Moore (AL) demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 354.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 8369, H.R. 7530, H.R. 7343, H.R. 8146, H.R. 7581, H.R. 354, H. Res. 1213 and H. Res. 1210. Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 8369, H.R. 7530, H.R. 7581, H.R. 354, H. Res. 1213, and H. Res. 1210 under a closed rule with one hour of general debate each. Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 7343 and H.R. 8146 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate each. Rule provides for one motion to recommit each on H.R. 8369, H.R. 7530, H.R. 7343, H.R. 7581, H.R. 354, and H.R. 8146.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 1227. H.R. 354 — "To amend title 18, United States Code, to improve the Law Enforcement Officer Safety Act and provisions relating to the carrying of concealed weapons by law enforcement officers, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 8369, the Chair put the question on the motion to recommit and by voice vote announced that the noes had prevailed. Mr. Meeks demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question on the motion to recommit was ordered pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XIX.
Mr. Meeks moved to recommit to the Committee on Foreign Affairs.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 8369.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 8369, H.R. 7530, H.R. 7343, H.R. 8146, H.R. 7581, H.R. 354, H. Res. 1213 and H. Res. 1210. Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 8369, H.R. 7530, H.R. 7581, H.R. 354, H. Res. 1213, and H. Res. 1210 under a closed rule with one hour of general debate each. Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 7343 and H.R. 8146 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate each. Rule provides for one motion to recommit each on H.R. 8369, H.R. 7530, H.R. 7343, H.R. 7581, H.R. 354, and H.R. 8146.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 1227. H.R. 8369 — "To provide for the expeditious delivery of defense articles and defense services for Israel and other matters."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Curtis to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal. Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 16.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mary E. Miller to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
